newsitem.title: FRANCE: French stocks end weaker, Lagardere seesaws.
newsitem.headline: French stocks end weaker, Lagardere seesaws.

text.p: French stocks ended a touch weaker on continued but limited consolidation on Tuesday with a see-saw day for magazines-to-missiles group Lagardere after the euphoric reaction to its planned takeover of Thomson SA.
The blue-chip CAC-40 index closed down 4.61 points or 0.21 percent at 2,175.61 while the CAC-40 futures contract fell five points to 2,182.0.
Volume was a healthy 5.02 billion francs, of which 3.3 billion was in the CAC-40 shares.
Overall, traders said a relatively robust market could see a bit more slippage -- to 2,150 according to some -- in the wake of a run which took the CAC-40 to a new high last Friday.

More than 3.5 million shares in Lagardere changed hands but a further surge of 5.3 percent soon petered out and the stock slid into the red in the afternoon on profit-taking, before creeping back to end at 177.8, up 0.68 percent.

Tuesday's announcement of a 38 percent jump in first-half net attributable profit to 409 million francs was sidelined by the continued focus on its plans to take over Thomson SA, which is being privatised.

Analysts and traders said a company presentation of the deal provided little new information but a cautious delivery provided room for a pause after the euphoric reaction that sent the stock soaring in recent days on the back of the Thomson news.
Oil giants Elf Aquitaine and Total both gained on oil price firmness, with Elf hitting a new high of 429.0 francs before both stocks eased off their session highs.

Thomson CSF was trading well above the 156 francs offered by Lagardere to buy out minority holders, with some traders talking of speculative buying in the hope that a higher buyout offer from the group could ultimately materialise.
